node.title: Denzel Washington, Man on Fire
node.description: The actor never leans in — he’s all in. And in his latest, “Macbeth,” conjured by Joel Coen, he is as sharp and deadly as a dagger.
node.content: ["When Denzel Washington and Frances McDormand began rehearsing to play the Macbeths, he asked her how she thought the couple had met.", "Oh, she replied blithely, the Macbeths met when they were 15. They were Romeo and Juliet, but they didn\u2019t commit suicide. They just stayed married for 50 years. But they didn\u2019t have any kids and his career stalled, so thinking legacy, they suddenly went gangster and killed their nice, old friend, the king.", "\u201cThis is one of the only good marriages in Shakespeare,\u201d said Joel Coen, who adapted and directed \u201cThe Tragedy of Macbeth,\u201d opening widely on Christmas Day. \u201cThey just happen to be plotting a murder.\u201d", "James Shapiro, a Shakespeare scholar at Columbia, backed up the director, adding dryly, \u201cBut there\u2019s not much competition, is there? The Capulets? Richard II and his nameless Queen? Richard III and the doomed widow, Anne?\u201d", "Now Mr. Coen and Ms. McDormand, who are married and who met on the Coen brothers\u2019 debut feature, the 1984 film noir \u201cBlood Simple,\u201d have teamed up with Mr. Washington to do another noir, the Scottish saga of \u201cBlood will have blood.\u201d", "As in all film noirs, the guy is a sap and the lady is trouble. Lady Macbeth pushes her husband into killing Duncan by taunting him about his manhood.", "When you watch Ms. McDormand \u2014 who defied all Hollywood odds to became a soaring star in middle age, specializing in playing women who, as she puts it, \u201care not necessarily redeemable\u201d \u2014 you absolutely believe she has the will for regicide.", "Mirroring the plot of \u201cMacbeth,\u201d Ms. McDormand pestered her reluctant husband until he gave in and agreed to direct the movie \u2014 without his (also reluctant) brother, Ethan, no less.", "\u201cFrances McDormand is a beast,\u201d Mr. Washington said, admiringly.", "A few weeks into filming, she asked her leading man if she had earned the right to call him \u201cD,\u201d as some close to him do.", "\u201cSure,\u201d he replied.", "Mr. Coen was amazed at what it was like to work with the pair, an old-school Hollywood matchup of titans. \u201cThey are such powerful, intuitive and fascinating performers,\u201d he said. \u201cYou were just floored by what happened on the set.\u201d He shot in a square \u201cacademy\u201d format, so it\u2019s all about the faces of Mr. Washington and Ms. McDormand filling the frame.", "\u201cThe three of us are at the top of our game,\u201d Ms. McDormand said. \u201cDenzel\u2019s 66. I\u2019m 64. Joel is 67. We\u2019re still taking risks. We\u2019re still willing to fall flat on our faces. Working with Denzel was delicious because of all those things.\u201d", "It was a tricky artistic three-way. She said that her husband had to trust that \u201cDenzel and I weren\u2019t going to gang up on him as actors,\u201d and Denzel had to trust that she and Joel \u201cweren\u2019t going to be too intimate as husband and wife.\u201d", "Over coffee at a Midtown Manhattan hotel, the morning after the movie\u2019s buzzy premiere at the New York Film Festival, Mr. Washington looked casual in black Under Armour sweats, but seemed beat.", "He said he had gotten very little sleep. He had just put the final touches on a film he directed, \u201cA Journal for Jordan,\u201d the true story of the romance between Dana Canedy , a former New York Times reporter and editor, and Sgt. Charles Monroe King, a soldier who was killed by a roadside bomb in Iraq, after meeting their infant son only once. It stars Michael B. Jordan and Chant\u00e9 Adams and also opens widely on Christmas Day.", "\u201cIt\u2019s just a beautiful story of loss and love,\u201d Mr. Washington said, \u201ca story about real heroes and sacrificing, men and women who have given their lives so that we have the freedom to complain.\u201d (The star, who has played a policeman more than a dozen times, recently made similar comments of respect for cops who put their lives on the line.)", "He said that before his 97-year-old mother died a few months ago, he promised her that he would \u201cattempt to honor her and God by living the rest of my days in a way that would make her proud. So that\u2019s what I\u2019m trying to do.\u201d", "\u201cI\u2019m more interested in directing because I\u2019m more interested in helping others,\u201d he said. \u201cWhat I do, what I make, what I made \u2014 all of that \u2014 is that going to help me on the last day of my life? It\u2019s about, Who have you lifted up? Who have we made better?", "\u201cThis is spiritual warfare. So, I\u2019m not looking at it from an earthly perspective. If you don\u2019t have a spiritual anchor you\u2019ll be easily blown by the wind and you\u2019ll be led to depression.\u201d", "Sounding like his father, a Pentecostal minister who died in 1991 \u2014 \u201cThat\u2019s what got my father, he couldn\u2019t give up the meat and fried foods\u201d \u2014 Mr. Washington asked me: \u201cHave you read the Bible? Start with the New Testament, because the Old Testament is harder. You get caught up in the who-begot-who-begot-who thing.\u201d", "He said he wants to mentor young actors like Mr. Jordan, Ms. Adams and Corey Hawkins, who did an acclaimed turn as Dr. Dre in \u201cStraight Outta Compton,\u201d and now plays Macduff, the lord who beheads Macbeth.", "Mr. Washington talked about working with the late Chadwick Boseman last year on his final film, \u201cMa Rainey\u2019s Black Bottom.\u201d", "Even before he met Mr. Boseman, Mr. Washington had agreed to Phylicia Rashad\u2019s request to help pay the young actor\u2019s tuition, along with eight other students at Howard University, to go to a summer acting program in England.", "\u201cHe was a brave young man, strong, and he had a strong woman next to him,\u2019\u2019 Mr. Washington recalled. \u201cOnce, I remember going in the trailer and thinking, Something is going on there. I didn\u2019t know what it was. Nobody did. Bless him. He kept it to himself and did his job. But he needed the time between takes to get his energy back.\u201d", "Mr. Hawkins said that he sometimes prayed with Mr. Washington on the \u201cMacbeth\u201d set in Burbank.", "\u201cSometimes we get talking and you see the preacher in him,\u201d the younger actor said. \u201cHe\u2019s just a natural-born charismatic leader who is not afraid to talk about his own faults or misgivings or shortcomings.\u201d", "Mr. Washington was eager to go to directing school under Mr. Coen, saying, \u201cJoel is just a genius, focused.\u201d", "Alex Hassell, a British actor who plays the Scottish royal, Ross, as a \u201csexy Rasputin,\u201d said that Mr. Washington often pressed Mr. Coen to explain his technique: \u201cDenzel would be asking, \u2018Why this? Why that?\u2019 He was so excited to get to work with Joel.\u201d", "Mr. Hassell said that Mr. Washington could go so \u201cdeep in his cortex\u201d that watching him was hypnotic, and he would sometimes forget to act. \u201cI\u2019d be like, \u2018Oh my God, oh, hang on. I was supposed to be there as well.\u2019 It might have just been him coming out of a tent. There is some quality that some people have which you just want to bottle.\u201d", "I read Mr. Washington a quote from Maya Angelou: \u201cDenzel Washington appears to me a classical contradiction,\u201d she said in the March 1994 issue of Ebony magazine \u201che is totally contained as a vault of rare gems and is as totally accessible as air.\u201d", "He smiled, saying, \u201cBeats a sharp stick in the eye, I guess.\u201d", "I wondered how he maintains an air of mystery in this oversharing era.", "\u201cIf they see you free all week, they won\u2019t pay to see you on the weekend,\u201d the star said. \u201cI don\u2019t tweet. I don\u2019t have Instagram. I embrace my inner analog.\u201d", "I told Mr. Washington that he is so peerless at speaking Shakespearean verse in a conversational way, he could be the love child of John Gielgud and Spencer Tracy.", "\u201cThat\u2019s 45 years of training,\u201d he said.", "When he was growing up in Mount Vernon, N.Y., a mentor told him, \u201cYour natural ability will only take you so far.\u201d With that in mind, after playing Othello at Fordham, he started searching for a school that would give him a foundation in the classics and ended up attending graduate school at the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco.", "\u201cThe whole thing with Joel and Fran was, they wanted \u2018No stick-up-the-butt Shakespeare,\u2019\u201d the actor said. They wanted \u201cdope Shakespeare,\u201d Mr. Hawkins added.", "Todd Black, Mr. Washington\u2019s producing partner, who worked with him on the movie versions of August Wilson\u2019s \u201cFences\u201d and \u201cMa Rainey\u2019s Black Bottom,\u201d said: \u201cHis whole thing with young people is \u2018Don\u2019t act.\u2019 He will stop an audition cold and say \u2018You\u2019re acting, please don\u2019t act.\u2019 He always checks their r\u00e9sum\u00e9s to see if they\u2019ve done theater.\u201d", "I asked Mr. Washington if Hollywood had become more diverse after #OscarsSoWhite.", "\u201cHollywood is a street,\u201d he said. \u201cI live in Los Angeles. I don\u2019t live in Hollywood. I don\u2019t know what Hollywood thinks. It\u2019s not like it\u2019s a bunch of people who get together on Tuesdays.\u201d", "When The Times\u2019s movie critics put Mr. Washington atop their list of the greatest 25 actors of the 21st century (so far), Manohla Dargis said that his dominance \u201cis a corrective and rebuke to the racist industry in which he works.\u201d", "\u201cOK,\u201d he said, chuckling, when I asked him about it. \u201cYou know, put the work out there and then people decide it\u2019s this, it\u2019s that.\u201d", "There were some who thought that after the Black Lives Matter protests, having a Black Macbeth would cause the play to resonate in a different way.", "At the start, Mr. Washington asked Mr. Coen about the black and white of it all. But it turned out he was just asking the director whether he was going to film in black and white. Mr. Washington believes that if you look at everything through the lens of a political agenda, you lose the plot as an artist.", "The director and his stars wanted to make a \u201cMacbeth\u201d that was universal, not topical.", "Ms. McDormand told me that she was not interested in modern interpretations of Macbeth as an emblem of toxic masculinity, or in correcting the stereotype of Lady Macbeth as a harridan.", "\u201cIt\u2019s banal\u201d to make Shakespeare politically correct, she sniffed. \u201cIt\u2019s bigger than that.\u201d", "But the casting still makes a difference. A fan approached Mr. Hawkins to tell him how amazing it was to see two Black actors, representing good and evil \u2014 Macduff and Macbeth \u2014 in the final, searing sword battle on a bridge.", "Mr. Coen goes for abstraction and chiaroscuro in the movie. Besides removing color, all the costumes and sets are stripped of ornamentation. The gray gloaming and hallucinatory mists envelop a spare and savage landscape, with the witches shape shifting into three black birds.", "The disorienting first scene features the whispery, scratchy voice of the staggering British actress Kathryn Hunter, who plays one witch divided into three; she sounds like she\u2019s gurgling blood.", "It\u2019s Mr. Coen\u2019s first cinematic adventure since his brother traded the silver screen for the stage \u2014 \u201cOf course, I missed him,\u201d Joel told me \u2014 and he doesn\u2019t want us to know if we\u2019re in Macbeth\u2019s wild mind or on the wild moors.", "\u201cIt\u2019s the essence of Joel, I have to say,\u201d Ms. McDormand said.", "The director was careful about fiddling with the verse, noting, \u201cYou don\u2019t want to sing the song without the melody.\u201d", "In keeping with the vision of a \u201cpostmenopausal\u201d Macbeth, they did change a line Macbeth speaks to his wife: \u201cBring forth men-children only/For thy undaunted mettle should compose/Nothing but male.\u201d \u201cShould compose\u201d has become \u201cshould have composed.\u201d", "\u201cThey\u2019re a couple at the end of their ambition, not at the beginning of their ambition,\u201d Ms. McDormand said. \u201cIn our interpretation, she starts realizing that she\u2019s become expendable and that\u2019s what drives her insane, not the fact that they kill Duncan and there\u2019s blood on her hands. She\u2019s given up her soul to the dark forces, and he\u2019s not confiding in her anymore. He\u2019s not asking for her help.\u201d", "The actress said that, for her and \u201cD,\u201d their long marriages provided insight: \u201cDenzel and Pauletta have been married as long as Joel and I have. We had to learn how to be parents together and life partners together because it\u2019s an ever-changing landscape.\u201d", "Mr. Coen said he wasn\u2019t scared of the Macbeth curse \u201cuntil Covid shut us down on Friday the 13th in March 2020.\u201d But Mr. Washington was never worried.", "\u201cI\u2019m a God-fearing man,\u201d he said. \u201cI try not to worry. Fear is contaminated faith.\u201d", "Unlike some other top movie stars, Mr. Washington is just as comfortable playing villains, antiheroes and deeply flawed men as he is portraying heroes. If there was ever any pressure on him, as there was on leading Black actors like Sidney Poitier back in the day, to choose saintly, role-model parts rather than demonic, criminal parts, he ignored it.", "\u201cWhat he decides he will do, he will do,\u201d said Brian Grazer, who produced Mr. Washington\u2019s hits \u201cAmerican Gangster\u201d and \u201cInside Man.\u201d \u201cWhat he decides he won\u2019t do, he won\u2019t do.\u201d", "The actor is nonpareil at playing lethal and unpredictable. His eyes can go dead and scary, full of razor blades, even as he offers that magnetic smile. In life, as in art, Mr. Grazer said, you know that this is not a guy you want to mess with.", "Mr. Washington was chilling as the bodyguard out for revenge in the 2004 film \u201cMan on Fire,\u201d and as the sociopathic L.A.P.D. narcotics cop Alonzo Harris in the 2001 thriller \u201cTraining Day,\u201d for which he won an Oscar.", "\u201c\u2018Training Day,\u2019 I ad-libbed, like, 50 percent of what you hear,\u201d Mr. Washington said. The director, Antoine Fuqua, used real Los Angeles gang members named Bone, Killer and Hitman as extras. \u201cWe had a lot of real folks that had done real things, so I used those people. I learned from those people.\u201d", "Ethan Hawke, who was taken on a terrifying ride as Jake Hoyt, Mr. Washington\u2019s tyro partner in that film, recalled the actor\u2019s threat of violence.", "\u201cIt was like playing music with Miles Davis or baseball with Babe Ruth,\u201d said Mr. Hawke, who was nominated for an Oscar for best supporting actor for his role. \u201cDenzel changed my life. To be 30 and get to work with one of the greats of all time? I\u2019ve never seen anybody be a flat-out better storyteller. He knows what the audience is thinking. He knows how to surprise them. His imagination is so thorough.", "\u201cThe greats can play offense and defense, and most people can\u2019t. Jack Nicholson, Gene Hackman and Denzel manage to be equally compelling as protagonist and antagonist.\u201d", "Mr. Washington\u2019s other co-stars are equally effusive.", "Meryl Streep talked to me about his \u201cmesmeric power over an audience\u201d onstage. Tom Hanks said, about their dazzling duet in \u201cPhiladelphia\u201d: \u201cI sat beside him for three weeks shooting the trial. I had no dialogue. It was a thriller of an acting class. He follows no rules but pursues the moment. No nonsense, but a looseness that can\u2019t be faked. A one-on-one scene with him is a game of hardball catch \u2014 he is both daring you to keep up and propelling you to do more.", "\u201cHe is our Brando. Nicholson. Olivier. And, like me, he steals office supplies and notebooks from the set dressing.\u201d", "Mr. Hanks recalled that, at one point on the set, \u201cWe were talking about our New York City days as broke actors \u2014 about the same age, peers, trying to learn craft and get work. I noted that we were in the same boat at the same time. \u2018Yeah,\u2019 he said. \u2018But you could catch a cab in Manhattan.\u2019\u201d", "Those who know Mr. Washington say he can be guarded; he can be suspicious of putting himself in others\u2019 hands, or of being taken out of context because he doesn\u2019t want to play into someone else\u2019s narrative. He keeps it low key, driving himself places without a posse. He isn\u2019t a regular on the Hollywood party scene.", "Actors who work with him are never sure where they stand. He can be charming or elusive, but not buddy-buddy.", "\u201cI did not try to be his friend, hang out at a Lakers game or go to birthday parties,\u201d Mr. Hawke said. \u201cI just wanted to offer him my best.\u201d", "Melissa Leo has worked with him in three movies \u2014 \u201cFlight\u201d and two of the \u201cEqualizer\u201d ones \u2014 and still calls him \u201cMr. Washington.\u201d", "Ms. McDormand agreed: \u201cHe\u2019s actually a really lovely human being but he does really need to protect his process. He has a very trusted team of people that he\u2019s worked with for years, that was his pod.\u201d", "When Liev Schreiber starred with Mr. Washington in \u201cThe Hurricane,\u201d he said he expected a friendly Denzel and got a prickly Hurricane instead.", "\u201cI thought he really hated me,\u201d Mr. Schreiber said. But later, he got a call from Jonathan Demme about appearing in \u201cThe Manchurian Candidate\u201d remake with Mr. Washington, who had pushed for him.", "\u201cI was completely shocked by that,\u201d Mr. Schreiber said. But, he added, Mr. Washington plumbs such dangerous and painful depths as an actor, that small talk could be distracting. \u201cI never worked with an actor who seemed to care more.\u201d", "Mr. Grazer said that Mr. Washington told him that he wouldn\u2019t play Frank Lucas in \u201cAmerican Gangster\u201d unless the Harlem murderer and drug trafficker was shown paying for his crimes in the end.", "Bruno Delbonnel, the brilliant French cinematographer for \u201cThe Tragedy of Macbeth,\u201d said that he is accustomed to being the first on set at 5 a.m., so he was surprised to see Mr. Washington beating him there.", "\u201cDenzel was there, always,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was a competition between him and me. He tried to beat me, because he was rehearsing alone for an hour or so on set with no light. Just himself walking on set and trying to have a feeling of what he could do.\u201d", "Mr. Washington doesn\u2019t whine. Spike Lee made his displeasure clear when Mr. Washington lost the Oscar in 1993 for his stunning performance in \u201cMalcolm X\u201d to Al Pacino for \u201cScent of a Woman,\u201d but Mr. Washington said graciously that if he had won, \u201cI would have felt badly. It was Pacino\u2019s time.\u201d", "When he accepted the American Film Institute Life Achievement Award in 2019, it was clear that he was getting more publicly spiritual. He called himself a vessel of God and played an old video of his late father-in-law talking about how we must love and care for one another. He talked disdainfully about the \u201cTwitter-tweet-meme-mean world that we\u2019ve created\u201d and said we\u2019d better do our best to \u201cturn this thing around\u201d for young people.", "He continued this theme at our coffee.", "\u201cThe enemy is the inner me,\u201d he said. \u201cThe Bible says in the last days \u2014 I don\u2019t know if it\u2019s the last days, it\u2019s not my place to know \u2014 but it says we\u2019ll be lovers of ourselves. The No. 1 photograph today is a selfie, \u2018Oh, me at the protest.\u2019 \u2018Me with the fire.\u2019 \u2018Follow me.\u2019 \u2018Listen to me.\u2019", "\u201cWe\u2019re living in a time where people are willing to do anything to get followed. What is the long or short-term effect of too much information? It\u2019s going fast and it can be manipulated obviously in a myriad of ways. And people are led like sheep to slaughter.\u201d", "In heaven, he said, \u201cthere are going to be two lines, the long line and the short line, and I\u2019m interested in being in the short line.\u201d", "He advises me to read The Daily Word, an inspirational message that has an app. (As I write, the daily word is \u201ccompassion.\u201d)", "\u201cYou have to fill up that bucket every morning,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s rough out there. You leave the house in the morning. Here they come, chipping away. By the end of the day, you\u2019ve got to refill that bucket. We know right from wrong.\u201d", "As he left, he turned back to remind me: \u201cGet that Daily Word.\u201d", "Maureen Dowd: Your doctor in \u201cSt. Elsewhere\u201d was hotter than George Clooney\u2019s doctor in \u201cER.\u201d", "Denzel Washington: I\u2019ve never seen George\u2019s doctor. I\u2019m not a television person.", "If Tarantino asks you to do his next and final movie, you\u2019ll do it.", "I haven\u2019t heard from him.", "Spike Lee was right about everything all along \u2014 except the Knicks.", "(Smiling) Everything? In life?", "You didn\u2019t understand the plot of \u201cTenet.\u201d", "Well, that\u2019s my son. I\u2019m proud of all my children.", "Growing up in the Pentecostal Church of God in Christ, you saw your share of glossolalia.", "Don\u2019t play with God. Don\u2019t play with God. You hear what I said? Don\u2019t play with God. You heard what I said? Don\u2019t play with God.", "Your mother differentiated you and your father by pronouncing his name DEN-zel and yours Den-ZEL.", "Yes, true.", "Your favorite food, after caviar, is H\u00e4agen-Dazs.", "(Smiling widely) Butter pecan. What do you like?"]
